subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Hi, folks
msgSnippet: Hi All, I ve been using Shavian, and now for some time Quikscript. I don t see the problem with all the question of accents. I ve always fallen back on the
messageBody:
Hi All,

I've been using Shavian, and now for some time
Quikscript. I don't see the problem with all the
question of accents. I've always fallen back on the
Webster's Dictiorary for the propper way to say
something. It or any other major dictionary gives you
the phonics of the word. Just like in a normal english
writing system, if you have a question of how it is
spelled, check the dictionary. At least in
Quickscript, it's phonic nature alls for even miss
spelled words to be pronounced.

Have a great day all,
Chuck

--- Dennis Falk <quozl1@...> wrote:
>
>
> On 8/9/2002 at 3:16 PM andy_callaway wrote:
>
> H'lo, Andy...
>
> >I've just joined this group. I've been interested
> in spelling reform
> >for a number of years now, and have been looking
> around at the
> >different alternatives. A couple of years ago, I
> got interested in
> >Shavian, and some time after that Quikscript.
>
> I'll throw a wrench in here.. ;) Most spelling
> reform schemes- particularly Shavian and Quikscript-
> really only work effectively with a particular
> accent, as they're not flexible enough to deal with
> unifying dialectual/accentual permutations (which
> are _usually_ consistant)- That is, under current
> Shavian and Quikscript schemes, no two accents will
> spell the same. (Not to mention that neither seem to
> accomodate borrowed phonetics used in English!)
>
> >Some of you may know my name. I see a couple of
> familiar names in
> >here, possible from
> alt.language.english.spelling.reform. I was the
> >one who created the Shaw Script font, and the
> Rosetta phonetic
> >translator.
>
> Andy, you know me from the Shavian group here at
> Yahoo!...
>
> D.M.Falk
>
>
>
>

Hi All,

I've been using Shavian, and now for some time 
Quikscript. I don't see the problem with all the
question of accents. I've always fallen back on the
Webster's Dictiorary for the propper way to say
something. It or any other major dictionary gives you
the phonics of the word. Just like in a normal english
writing system, if you have a question of how it is
spelled, check the dictionary. At least in
Quickscript, it's phonic nature alls for even miss
spelled words to be pronounced.

Have a great day all,
Chuck
